child.geography: Akunnu, Asẹ, Ikaram, Ibaram, Iyani, Gedegede, Daja, and Esuku
child.pub-comments: The author notes on page 80 that the term 'Akpes' is not acceptable to all speakers, but a more acceptable term has not yet been established.

child.pub-comments: "Two languages, Ayere and Ahan, are related to one another and may also be related to Akokoid, although information on these two communities is presently too meagre to make and definitive statement" (Ohiri-Aniche: 1999 80).

child.geography: The towns and communities of Ukare (Ikare), Irun, Ọ̀kà, Orà, Ifira, Afo, Idoani (Amusigbo and Isure quarters), Imeri, Ikun, Ugbe (Igbe), Boropa (Ìbòròkpá), Supare (ʃúkpare), Ipesi (Ìkpèsi), Àkùngbá, Ọ́bà
child.pub-comments: "Monolingual Yoruba speakers form the majority of the population of the Akoko area" (Ohiri-Aniche: 1999 80).

child.publications: Ohiri-Aniche, Chinyere. 1999. Langugage diversification in the Akoko area of Western Nigeria. In Roger Blench & Matthew Spriggs (eds.), Archaeolgy and Language IV: Language Change and Cultural Transformation, 79-94. London and New York: Routledge: Taylor & Francis Group.
